info.headline: Flood Advisory issued January 08 at 4:32PM EST until January 11 at 1:00PM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...The National Weather Service in Greenville-Spartanburg has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in North Carolina... French Broad River At Asheville affecting Buncombe County. French Broad River At Marshall affecting Madison County. .A potent storm system is expected to produce 4-6 inches of rainfall across the upper French Broad River watershed and 1.5-3 inches of rainfall across the middle and lower French Broad River watershed from early Tuesday morning through Tuesday evening. This rainfall will quickly overwhelm saturated soils and result in excessive runoff and significant stream rises throughout the French Broad River valley. Nuisance to Minor flooding of some tributaries, including the Ivy River, is possible beginning late Tuesday morning or early Tuesday afternoon. This excessive flow will cause portions of the French Broad River from Bent Creek downstream to Biltmore, Asheville, Woodfin, and Marshall to exceed Action/Advisory Stage late Tuesday evening into early Wednesday morning, causing common, nuisance flooding of low-lying areas. If rainfall totals significantly exceed current forecasts, higher crests across the middle and lower French Broad River may occur, resulting in deeper inundation of common, flood-prone areas adjacent to the river. If necessary, a River Flood Warning may be required. Residents, business owners, and recreational river users are encouraged to stay up-to-date by monitoring the latest river levels and forecasts, as conditions may change quickly. ...FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON TO EARLY THURSDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Nuisance flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected. Minor flooding is possible. * WHERE...French Broad River at Asheville. * WHEN...From this afternoon to early Thursday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 8.0 feet, Action/Advisory Stage flooding continues. The French Broad River is beginning to flood low-lying areas near Pearson Bridge Rd. and may be approaching industrial property. At 9.5 feet, Minor Flood Stage. The French Broad River is flooding areas between Riverside Dr., and Lyman St. on the right bank and Riverview Dr., Craven St. and Emma Rd. on the left bank, including railroad and industrial property. Parts of Emma Rd. between Pearson Bridge Rd. and Craven St. may be flooding. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:30 PM EST Monday the stage was 2.0 feet and falling slowly. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 8.5 feet Wednesday morning. The river may continue to rise to near or just above Minor Flood Stage Wednesday morning. If the river significantly exceeds Minor Flood Stage, a River Flood Warning may be issued. Please closely monitor the latest levels and forecasts. - Action/Advisory Stage is 6.5 feet. - Minor Flood Stage is 9.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: If you encounter a flooded roadway, turn around and find an alternative route. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. If you are in the advisory area, remain alert to possible flooding or the possibility of the advisory being upgraded to a warning. For detailed information including observed and forecast stages, flood impacts, flood history, FEMA Flood Hazard Layers, and more, please visit: https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=gsp The next statement will be issued before Wednesday evening at 730 PM EST.
